javaslang.algebra

Interface Monad<T>

  • Type Parameters:
    T - component type of this monad
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    Arbitrary<T>, Future<T>, Gen<T>, IndexedSeq<T>, Iterator<T>, LinearSeq<T>, List<T>, Map<K,V>, Match.MatchMonad<R>, Option<T>, Seq<T>, Set<T>, SortedMap<K,V>, SortedSet<T>, Stack<T>, Stream<T>, Traversable<T>, Tree<T>, Try<T>, Value<T>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractIterator, Array, CharSeq, Either.LeftProjection, Either.RightProjection, Failure, HashMap, HashSet, Lazy, List.Cons, List.Nil, Match.MatchMonad.Otherwise, Match.MatchMonad.When.Then, None, Queue, Some, Stream.Cons, Stream.Empty, Success, Tree.Empty, Tree.Node, TreeMap, TreeSet, Vector

    public interface Monad<T>
    Defines a Monad by generalizing the flatMap function.

    All instances of the Monad interface should obey the three control laws:

    • Left identity: unit(a).flatMap(f) ≡ f a
    • Right identity: m.flatMap(unit) ≡ m
    • Associativity: m.flatMap(f).flatMap(g) ≡ m.flatMap(x -> f.apply(x).flatMap(g)
    given
    • an object m of type Monad<A>
    • an object a of type A
    • a constructor unit taking an a and producing an object of type Monad<A>
    • a function f: A → M
    To read further about monads in Java please refer to What's Wrong in Java 8, Part IV: Monads.
    Since:
    1.1.0
    Author:
    Daniel Dietrich

    • Method Detail

      • filter

        Monad<T> filter(Predicate<? super T> predicate)
        Filters this Monad by testing a predicate.

        The semantics may vary from class to class, e.g. for single-valued type (like Option) and multi-values types (like Traversable). The commonality is, that filtered.isEmpty() will return true, if no element satisfied the given predicate.

        Also, an implementation may throw NoSuchElementException, if no element makes it through the filter and this state cannot be reflected. E.g. this is the case for Either.LeftProjection and Either.RightProjection.

        Parameters:
        predicate - A predicate
        Returns:
        a new Monad instance
        Throws:
        NullPointerException - if predicate is null

      • flatten

        <U> Monad<U> flatten()
        Flattens this Monad by one level.

        Example: 

        List(Some(1), Some(2), None).flatten() = List(1, 2)
        Caution: Effectively flatMap(Function.identity()) is called. That requires this elements to be of type java.lang.Iterable<U>. More specifically this type FilterMonadic<T> has to be of type FilterMonadic<? extends java.lang.Iterable<U>> for some given U. We (currently) can't express this constraint with Java's type system. If this type does not fulfill the requirement at runtime, a ClassCastException is thrown.

        It is unsafe to use flatten(). Especially this compiles but throws at runtime: 

        // Compiles. Throws at runtime because elements are not Iterable!
 List<String> list = List(1, 2, 3).flatten();
        Also beware of the following exceptional cases: CharSeq.flatten() and Map.flatten().
        Type Parameters:
        U - the nested component type
        Returns:
        A flattened version of this Monad.
        Throws:
        UnsupportedOperationException - if this elements are not of type ? extends java.lang.Iterable<? extends T>.

      • flatMap
